events.title: 2xAA plays his Game Boy
events.subtitle: Live chiptune performance
events.abstract: A performance and talk about the chiptune music I create on my Game Boy, along with specially written visuals to go along with the set.

events.title: 5 Scientific Tools That'll Blow Your Mind
events.abstract: Back in the days when I was a professional, card-carrying scientist, I was fascinated by the various tools that were being developed to measure very small things, very precisely. This talk covers some of the ones that really stuck, the ones that make you go "Really?? That's possible?"

events.title: A brief guide to dog behaviour and human interaction
events.abstract: A talk about dog behaviour and communication. This is especially targeted at anyone afraid of dogs but is relevant to anyone looking to understand the basics of canine communication and how it affects their interactions with humans and other creatures.

events.title: Advanced Blacksmithing
events.abstract: An advanced blacksmithing workshop for those who have taken a blacksmithing course at EMF this year or in 2012.

events.title: A look at Linux containers, what they do and what they don't
events.abstract: A deep dive into cgroups, unshare and other technologies in the Linux kernel used to create isolated containers (as used by Docker/lxc).

events.title: Amateur Radio: The Original Nerd Hobby!
events.abstract: I find great satisfaction entering an aspect of the past and exploring the elements of how we communicate: radio! It's the culture that evolved nerdiness - let's explore our roots and why it still exists!

events.title: An Introduction to Glitch Art
events.abstract: In this part theory, part practice workshop participants will be given a brief introduction into Glitch Art and its impact on art, music and popular culture. Participants will then have a practice session where they will delve into the common techniques utilised by glitch artists. Participants will need a laptop/computer (Mac/Windows/Linux) with the following software installed: GIMP, Audacity, a hex editor, and a good text editor such as Notepad++.

events.title: An Operator's Guide to the Enigma Cipher Machine
events.abstract: Simon Singh, bestselling author of Fermat's Last Theorem & The Code Book, discusses the German Enigma cipher machine and how it was cracked during the Second World War by British codebreakers at Bletchley Park. This talk will include a demonstration of a genuine Enigma cipher machine. He'll also discuss the history of encryption from Ancient Greece through to the Information Age.

events.title: An unofficial tour of EMF
events.subtitle: Who made it happen, how and why
events.abstract: To give attendees some insight into how the camp comes into being, I intend to lead them around the site on a bumbling tour, pointing out bits of information so far only privy to the volunteers who organised it.

events.title: Arm Knitting
events.abstract: Use your arm, instead of needles, to knit with. This fun technique allows you to make a scarf very quickly. No knitting experience necessary. All equipment provided.

events.title: A Tune On A Stick
events.abstract: Rotating collaborative musical sequencer thing.

events.title: bach.js, an unhistory of how the great Baroque composer pioneered Javascript, 250 years before Netscape even existed
events.abstract: Participants in this very special JS Bachshop will have the opportunity to consider the use of motifs to ease maintainability, the difficulties of using callbacks to implement counterpoint, recently-unearthed innovations in Baroque-Driven Development, and just how far you can stretch a single pun. Audience participation recommended, and will probably involve singing or pretending to be the Elector of Saxony. May contain more music than Javascript, anecdotes about fainting trumpeters, and a diversion into ways of rehearsing the dissonant call of “Barabbas” in SMP 54.

events.title: Back to Basics Radio
events.subtitle: Build a self-powered solderless radio receiver
events.abstract: Using only basic parts we will build a simple "crystal set" radio receiver which requires no battery to operate.

events.title: BaseBot
events.subtitle: A cheap, mobile, open source, physical computing platform for education
events.abstract: The BaseBot is a set of laser cut templates, circuit boards and easily sourced standard hardware which acts as a base for experimentation and education with mobile physical computing.

events.title: Beyond Materials: Invisibility and Perfect Imaging
events.abstract: I will talk about my PhD which is on using metamaterials and transformation optics to create invisibility cloaks and perfect Imaging devices. (Working invisibility cloak prototypes will not be provided)

events.title: BigHak
events.subtitle: Created as a collaborative project by the Hitchin Hackspace team, bighak is a giant ride-on homage to bigtrak.

events.title: Build your own quadrotor from scratch
events.abstract: A talk about building UAVs, in particular quadrotors, from scratch, in an age where it's easy to buy them ready-made, or in kit form where you just have to plug a few components together.

events.title: Bunting and Decorations
events.subtitle: Decorate the Nanotechs Area!
events.abstract: Help decorate the Kids Area! All ages, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki.

events.title: Can open data help save the world?
events.abstract: Open data is a force that will change the world – we hope for the better. It's hard to imagine how we might scale society without it. I'll talk about the Open Data Institute's experiences at the front-line over the last 2 years, and what we think might happen next (I run the ODI).

events.title: Collaborative Science Fiction Film made at EMF
events.abstract: A showing of the science fiction film that has been filmed around the EMF site during the event, along with a Q&A with the team.

events.title: Collaborative Storytelling
events.abstract: Children able to write short sentences (or accompanied by a parent or guardian who can help them write) will be arranged in a circle and each given an oversized sheet of paper. After writing the first sentence for their story they pass it to the next child who writes the second sentence and folds over the top of the paper, making it impossible to see the first sentence before passing the sheet on to have the third sentence written by the next child. Each child is only able to see the sentence before theirs and not the rest of the back story as they write the next part of the collaborative stories. When the papers get back to the original owners, they can read what the results are in turn. Ages 8+. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki.

events.title: Contributing to OpenStreetMap
events.abstract: An introduction to basic editing of OpenStreetMap using the in-browser editor Potlatch2. Please bring a laptop.

events.title: Cooking: Braai (BBQ)
events.abstract: £10 per participant (all you can eat).

events.title: Cooking & tasting workshop: Erwtensoep (Green pea soup)
events.abstract: £2 per participant (you'll get at least one portion of the soup). With rookworst, bacon, roggebrood with cooked bacon, and much more!

events.title: Cooking workshop: King-size pannenkoeken (Dutch pancakes)
events.abstract: Price: £2 per pancake (42 cm! These easily feed one generic-sized adult). Toppings include bacon, cheese, strawberry jam, stroop, sugar, etc.

events.title: Cryptris
events.subtitle: Explaining cryptography to non-specialists through playing Tetris
events.abstract: Developed alongside PhD research into a new cryptographic protocol, Cryptris is a game that seeks to explain to the public the principles of asymmetric cryptography. The game explains the concepts of added randomness, cyclical operations and addition graphically to show how keys unlock messages.

events.title: DDD: Disney Driven Development
events.subtitle: How Disney's Four Keys can be applied to web development
events.abstract: A talk about Disney's four keys (Safety, Courtesy, Efficiency, Show), giving examples of how Disney uses them in building their parks, and how we apply them to web development.

events.title: Democracy Meetup
events.abstract: Come along and discuss ideas around democratic participation, online democracy, and more. If you enjoyed the democracy talks from Tom Watson, Dan Jellinek, and James Smith, drop in and add your own ideas.

events.title: Demoscene Showcase
events.abstract: An introduction to the demoscene and a show of the results from the demoscene competitions that have been going on in the demoscene village.

events.title: Dermot Jones plays Spanish guitar
events.subtitle: Dermot performing a few of his self-scrawled-lyrically-vivid acoustic songs and and range of instrumental covers: from Bowie to (Scott) Joplin!
events.abstract: Me and a Spanish guitar. My biggest enthusiasms in music are The Kinks and Snooks Eaglin, and it shows!

events.title: Disruptive disintermediation: selling open digital health services to the NHS
events.abstract: I'll provide a short update on progress made in the campaign to make NHS IT less bad.

events.title: DIY Physio for Geeks
events.abstract: This hands-on workshop will cover a quick introduction to the muscles in the back and a hands-on, do-it-yourself guided exercise to release the muscles in your back and neck. Each person works on their own; tennis balls will be provided.

events.title: DNA Bracelets
events.abstract: Create a bracelet or necklace based on the DNA of a spitting cobra or a sweet orange. This would probably need a little bit of adult help, particularly for the younger ones. All ages, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki.

events.title: EMF 2014 Opening ceremony
events.abstract: It begins!

events.title: EMF 2014 retrospective: What did we do right?
EMF network in a field 2014
events.subtitle: What we did and how you used it
events.abstract: We will give a short talk detailing how we set up the network, brought high-speed Internet to the farm, and delivered wired and wirelessly across the site. Particularly we'll talk about what we did differently this time around, what went well, what proved more of a hurdle than expected, and finally we'll go through some stats on how the network was used.

events.title: Emojli: How we accidentally built an app and why we never want to build one again.
events.abstract: We came up with a terrible idea for an app. A week later, 70,000 people had signed up for it. We hadn't even built the thing. Learn from our story of woe, and don't ever build an app.

events.title: Evading Anti-virus
events.abstract: A exploration into current techniques malicious hackers use to evade anti-virus systems, presented in a way that less technical attendees can still enjoy whilst containing enough detail to keep more experienced viewers interested.

events.title: Experimental/Noise DJ-Set/Performance
events.abstract: Experimental & Noise DJ-Set/Performance includes mix selection of new and old classics noise and extreme sounds.

events.title: Fakebit Polytechnic
events.subtitle: Wiimote-controlled chiptune-inspired lo-fi synthpop from Dave Green (former NTK editor) & Dave Pape (Museum of Techno)
events.abstract: Wiimote-controlled chiptune-inspired lo-fi synthpop from Dave Green (former NTK editor) & Dave Pape (Museum of Techno).

events.title: Futures of Sexual Healthcare and Digital Fabrication
events.abstract: This workshop explores the future of sexual healthcare provision, and the role that digital fabrication (3D printing) might play in it. There’s a long history of localised grassroots innovation around sexual health, and lots of projects exploring what 3D printing has to offer to medicine and healthcare. In this workshop, we bring these two elements together.

events.title: Fuzzy Fuzzy Logic
events.abstract: Fuzzy logic is used widely in electronic, engineering and robotic applications for dealing with uncertainty. However it is ill suited for certain types of problems, in which it doesn't model uncertainty with enough accuracy. This talk will give an overview of the emerging field of type-2 fuzzy logic, and how and what you can do with it in the real world today.

events.title: Games Minus Industry
events.abstract: Videogames mash all media together with system design, making them inherently flexible in a way nothing else has ever been. Unfortunately, they're also tragically limited by over-dependence on industry and commercially appealing genres. I'll use mountain biking to unpick Super Hexagon, and then the pieces of both to unpick the divergence between the innate weirdness of videogames and the games industry's entrenched resistance to that.

events.title: Gasman's ZX Spectrum Chiptune Extravaganza
events.abstract: I'll perform bleepy electronic music with a Sinclair ZX Spectrum, keytar and vocoder. My set consists of pop covers, classic tracks from the PC and Amiga demo scene, and original music.

events.title: Gasman's ZX Spectrum Chiptune Extravaganza Part II
events.abstract: I'll perform bleepy electronic music with a Sinclair ZX Spectrum, keytar and vocoder. My set consists of pop covers, classic tracks from the PC and Amiga demo scene, and original music.

events.title: Geocaching!
events.abstract: We'll go for a geocaching walk around the area. There are loads around and we can decide how many we want to do when we all meet up.

events.title: Glass music, the nervous system, mesmerism and the threshold of beauty and harmony
events.abstract: A thorough history of the musical instrument of the 1800s, the Armonica, and its connections to mesmerism. My talk would give a short explanation of how an Armonica works, before expanding upon its connections to mesmerism and feminine distance.

events.title: Google Cardboard VR Goggles Workshop
events.abstract: A workshop to make Google Cardboard Virtual Reality goggles. Each kit will cost £10. https://cardboard.withgoogle.com

events.title: Google Cardboard VR Goggles Workshop
events.abstract: A workshop to make Google Cardboard Virtual Reality goggles. Each kit will cost £10. https://cardboard.withgoogle.com

events.title: Google Cardboard VR Goggles Workshop
events.abstract: A workshop to make Google Cardboard Virtual Reality goggles. Each kit will cost £10. https://cardboard.withgoogle.com

events.title: GPG/PGP Keysigning
events.abstract: A chance to get your GPG/PGP key signed! Bring keyslips and some photo ID.

events.title: Hackerspaces and Diversity
events.subtitle: A critical look at the communities, organisations and places
events.abstract: A talk about hackerspaces, the problems with them, and how you can help combat those problems.

events.title: Hacking and healthcare
events.subtitle: What you can do to monitor yourself
events.abstract: A talk covering the basics of health, what you should be doing, and monitoring yourself at home.

events.title: Hacking biometric security
events.abstract: A talk about how biometrics are not always secure, & the security systems are often poorly implemented.

events.title: Hacking the ZX Spectrum
events.abstract: Ben Heck, famed retro console modder and youtube star, will be talking about how he recently miniaturised a ZX Spectrum to make it portable and playable on-the-go. He’ll also be talking about some of his other mods that have been widely publicised over the years.

events.title: Hacking TiLDA MKe
events.subtitle: How to write Firmware for your EMF badge
events.abstract: This workshop will will cover how to set up the Arduino IDE and how to write and upload a working "Hello World" App. It will also cover an overview of the API and components such as the radio, orientation/acceleration sensors, sound, RGB, etc. Please bring your own laptop and micro USB cable!

events.title: Hexayurts, Distributed Infrastructure, and Maximizing Global Minimalism
events.abstract: The Hexayurt Project is an open source housing project with > 1000 units deployed each year. However, there's more to the story - a transformation vision about how engineering "outside of the market" can change the world in ways that markets cannot manage. Over three billion people live substantially outside of the market: where could they go with with this technology?

events.title: High Altitude Ballooning
events.abstract: We'll cover all the basics of high altitude ballooning and share some stories from years of HAB experience. Designing your own flight, what you'll need, things to consider, and top tips to ensure a good result. As an added incentive, we'll be assembling and launching our own high altitude balloon right after the talk! Come and see a real HAB launch and stick around to watch us track it and receive telemetry live.

events.title: High Altitude Balloon Launch
events.abstract: A high altitude balloon launch and tracking! (Near A2, opposite side of the lake to the grid)

events.title: High Altitude Balloon Launch
events.abstract: A high altitude balloon launch and tracking! (Near A2, opposite side of the lake to the grid)

events.title: History of Rocketry
events.abstract: A look at the history of rocketry over the last two and a half thousand years, from ancient Greece to the modern day.  Along the way we make an aeolipile, a gunpowder flash, and even set off a live hybrid rocket engine.

events.title: Home-Grown Bioscience
events.abstract: Home-grown biosciences and advances in engineering allow us to re-imagine the manufacturing of dyes and fabrics. Instead of exploiting and destroying nature for materials, can we create a future of synbiotic collaboration with nature? We will show off glowing bacteria, create microbe paintings with colour producing bacteria, show off how bio-leather can be grown from tea, and much more. Ages 14+. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki.

events.title: How buying multiple train tickets can be much cheaper than one
events.abstract: Due to the horrendous complexity of the British railway system, it is possible to buy more than one train ticket for a journey - for exactly the same trains - and save upwards of 70% on the cost of the ticket. Hear how this works and the site I built that helps you find these savings.

events.title: How Life Reflects Numbers and Numbers Reflect Life
events.subtitle: Alex Through The Looking Glass
events.abstract: What's the world's favourite number? How do numbers unconsciously influence decision-making? And what has Eratosthenes got to do with spaceships? I'll answer all these questions and more in a one hour talk about my latest book.

events.title: How Many Bugs Can a Time Server Have?
events.subtitle: Tim and Mike will talk about a number of new advisories (to be released on the 29th), including remote root in a network device.
events.abstract: Tim and Mike will talk about a number of new advisories (to be released on the 29th), including remote root in a network device.

events.title: How the Russians did cold-war portable radio
events.abstract: Chewie will give a mini tour of the Russian ZIL131 radio truck, and try and answer questions about it (he has only has it for 3 months). Meet at the truck for an explanation of how and why. Location: caravan field. Look for the red flag.

events.title: How to be an Effective Terrorist: fear and loathing in cyber security
events.abstract: Dr Jessica Barker is a security consultant often present in the media helping people to understand the threats they are exposed to. She’ll be talking about how we should be explaining risks rather than hiding them from users, allowing people to effectively manage their online activity and protect themselves.

events.title: How to catch a cat burglar with a Slice of Pi
events.abstract: I'm new to the Raspberry Pi. This is the story of how I embarked on a project to catch fly tippers on our local farms, but got distracted trying to frighten kids at Halloween, and discovered I'm  feeding the local feline population.

events.title: How to stand for Parliament
events.subtitle: Opening up the hidden world of democratic participation
events.abstract: I'm a geek standing as an MP next year, and I'm learning how it all works as I go along, blogging and publishing open data wherever possible. I'll talk all about what I've found out so far, what's left to learn, and how easy it really is to stand up for a better future.

events.title: How to use Twilio in ten minutes flat
events.abstract: A very quick demonstration of how to use Twilio in under ten minutes. Expect audience participation!

events.title: How we spent a year building a spaceship simulator in a caravan
events.abstract: A year ago we bought an old caravan and converted it into a 3 player starship disaster simulator called the "LHS Bikeshed". This is the story of how we've done it and not torn out all of our hair in the process.

events.title: InfraRed Communications
events.abstract: A bit of theory on how InfraRed (IR) communications work along with some practical exercises demonstrating IR comms in operation.  With the option for people to make their own little IR transmitting and/or receiving device (depending on skill level). Please bring a laptop if possible, and feel free to bring an IR remote or small IR-controlled device if you have one.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction to Blacksmithing
events.abstract: A beginners introduction to blacksmithing. All participants will leave the workshop with a piece of blacksmithing they've made themselves. This workshop costs £20 per person.

events.title: Introduction To Electronic Fashion Workshop
events.abstract: Learn about the materials, equipment and techniques which can be used to construct electronic fashion, e-textile and wearable projects.  You'll get to sew a simple electronic circuit on to a piece of fabric. This workshop will cost £8.

events.title: Introduction to Information Security and Privacy
events.abstract: This talk will give an overview of the range of threats from public and private organisations and the various measures to deal with them. You will be taught what tools to use (and not use) under certain conditions and how to overcome state-level attacks against your communications on a shoestring budget should you need it.

events.title: IoT: Making it through the Perfect Day
events.subtitle: Home automation using a MIPS connected processor board
events.abstract: Imagination Technologies will take you through the development of a home automation system using a MIPS development board. Laptops required, but all other hardware will be supplied.

events.title: Kite-Mapping Part 1
events.abstract:
In this 2-part workshop we will roll up our sleeves and learn about DIY aerial photography using kites: we'll fly a kite, map an area of Bletchley Park, learn how to make a composite aerial photograph using MapKnitter, and learn how to interpret aerial photos, their uses, and examples of how/where DIY mapping has been used around the world (including how this all began during the BP oilspill in the Gulf of Mexico 2010). No prior experience is required. This method is a Public Laboratory for Open Technology and Science open source prototype. In the first part of this session we will gather data flying a kite over Bletchley Park - everyone, young and old, will get to fly the kites and attach the camera to the kite line but not before learning about the technical and safety bits of DIY kite mapping. In the second part we will learn how to make a map using the images we collect, interpret them, learn about and create ideas about how these can help us tell a story of the spaces we map, whether these be our communities, public space, our schools, natural areas, farms, etc. We will also talk about the ethics of mapping and the relevance of community mapping and activism. Ages 8+. Bring:
  • a fleece or/and wind breaker
  • sunglasses (we'll be staring up at the sky a lot!)
  • sunscreen and/or hat (that won't fly away!)
  • water bottle
  • a laptop computer (good to have but not absolutely necessary - we can pair up)
  • a USB memory stick 4Gb or bigger to store aerial imagery
  • optional: an SD card (to be sent up in a camera with the kite)
More info on the wiki.

events.title: Kite-Mapping Part 2
events.abstract:
In this 2-part workshop we will roll up our sleeves and learn about DIY aerial photography using kites: we'll fly a kite, map an area of Bletchley Park, learn how to make a composite aerial photograph using MapKnitter, and learn how to interpret aerial photos, their uses, and examples of how/where DIY mapping has been used around the world (including how this all began during the BP oilspill in the Gulf of Mexico 2010). No prior experience is required. This method is a Public Laboratory for Open Technology and Science open source prototype. In the first part of this session we will gather data flying a kite over Bletchley Park - everyone, young and old, will get to fly the kites and attach the camera to the kite line but not before learning about the technical and safety bits of DIY kite mapping. In the second part we will learn how to make a map using the images we collect, interpret them, learn about and create ideas about how these can help us tell a story of the spaces we map, whether these be our communities, public space, our schools, natural areas, farms, etc. We will also talk about the ethics of mapping and the relevance of community mapping and activism. Ages 8+. Bring:
  • a fleece or/and wind breaker
  • sunglasses (we'll be staring up at the sky a lot!)
  • sunscreen and/or hat (that won't fly away!)
  • water bottle
  • a laptop computer (good to have but not absolutely necessary - we can pair up)
  • a USB memory stick 4Gb or bigger to store aerial imagery
  • optional: an SD card (to be sent up in a camera with the kite)
More info on the wiki.

events.title: LaserTag - Games of Quasar!
events.abstract: LaserTag games, somewhere on site!

events.title: LaserTag - How Quasar works
events.abstract: An introduction in to how the Quasar lasertag game works, a very brief history (to put in to context the age of the base design), and some demonstrations of it in operation, and some recent enhancements added.

events.title: Learning to Make – How I built an electromechanical display and taught myself basic electronics
events.abstract: Over the past 5 years since the final year of my undergraduate degree in 2009 I have been building a split-flap display (departure board) like you'd have seen at train stations and airports several years ago. This talk is about how I learnt almost everything I know through curiosity, trying, and making and iterating.

events.title: Learn to knit
events.abstract: A workshop teaching the basics of knitting, wool and needles provided.

events.title: Learn to solder
events.abstract: Never soldered before or been so long you need a refresher? Make a flashing LED badge and learn basic soldering techniques. Badge kit costs £2.

events.title: LHS bikeshed - A spaceship disaster simulator in a caravan
Lightning Talks - Sign up at the Info Tent!
events.abstract: An hour of lightning talks, ten minutes per talk. If you'd like to take part sign up in advance at the Info Tent, or show up just before and see if there's a slot free.

events.title: Lightning Talks - Sign up at the Info Tent!
events.abstract: An hour of lightning talks, ten minutes per talk. If you'd like to take part sign up in advance at the Info Tent, or show up just before and see if there's a slot free.

events.title: Lightning Talks - Sign up at the Info Tesk!
events.abstract: An hour of lightning talks, ten minutes per talk. If you'd like to take part sign up in advance at the Info Tent, or show up just before and see if there's a slot free.

events.title: Live coded techno
events.abstract: An improvised, live coded "algorave" style electronic dance music performance using the Tidal DSL.

events.title: Machine learning and its use in creepy internet stalking
events.abstract: This presentation will discuss the extreme vulnerability that most people have to being stalked online and then focusing on a few examples of research going on in universities on network inference. The purpose of this talk is to shed light on the topic of social network inference and show yet another application of machine learning.

events.title: Make a Lightsaber
events.abstract: Making lightsabers from Pool Noodles, gaffer tape and marker pens. All ages, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki.

events.title: Make a Lightsaber and Drop-in Crafts
events.abstract: Help decorate the Kids Area! All ages, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki. You will need to sign up to make a lightsaber, but you can also drop-in for storytelling and crafts!

events.title: Make metal castings from 3D Printed Moulds
events.abstract: Traditional metal casting can make parts of very high strengths, and 3D printing can produce things quickly out of fragile plastic parts. However the two processes can be joined, to produce the mould from a home-made 3D printer for use to make traditional metal castings. This talk will focus on the use of 3D printed parts to make investment castings in Aluminium.

events.title: MaKey MaKey
events.abstract: Makey makey is an invention kit that lets you transform everyday objects into computer keys. For example, you can make a game controller out of play-doh or a piano out of bananas. In this workshop you will get a chance to create your own playful inventions using makey makey, Scratch, and everyday materials such as foil, foam, furniture, and even people. All ages, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. You will need to bring a laptop. More info on the wiki.

events.title: Make your own titanium spork
events.abstract: Participants will design & make their own titanium spork from sheet metal, with a few simple hand tools. All equipment provided.

events.title: Making rope from nettles
events.abstract: A chance to learn how to pick nettles and turn them into string which can then be turned into rope.

events.title: Materials and Makers
events.subtitle: Thinking about Processes, Products and Supply Chains
events.abstract: 3D printing is opening up new opportunities to make complex or one-off objects. But makers need to think about materials: What materials can be used, how processing affects the properties, and the post-processing of fabricated objects.

events.title: MEGA GIRP
events.abstract: On stage you'll find a grid of letters, and on the projector you'll find a climbing wall. Contort yourself to try and climb the wall, or just watch others and shout advice!

events.title: Mega Hammock
events.abstract: A huge multi-person hammock.

events.title: Mesh Your Brain
events.subtitle: Simple EEG + Networked Robots
events.abstract: First, a quick overview of current hacker-friendly EEG systems. Then, a more in-depth look at how to hack together a robot army with the NeuroSky MindFlex and a Pinoccio microcontroller.

events.title: Meteonome
events.subtitle: A musical performance controlled by the weather

events.title: Minimal effort web application security (a.k.a. how to make my job harder)
events.abstract: In this talk I will present a few quick tips on making your web applications more resistant to common attack vectors, without putting a lot of effort in. In some cases, simply adding a line to a configuration file can completely prevent entire classes of attack from being viable. We'll take a look at hardening against XSS, SQL injection, clickjacking, password cracking, and a few other bits if there's time. With any luck, you'll make my job a bit more difficult.

events.title: Miracle cures, superpowers and the zombie apocalypse
events.subtitle: The current and future state of gene therapy in humans
events.abstract: A quick introduction to the underlying biology behind gene therapy and the challenges involved, how it's done, and what we're likely to see emerging into mainstream medicine over the next few years. Then we'll explore some plausible trends for the future of the technology, and end with a few questions about some odd new ethical issues that we'll need to find answers to.

events.title: Multicast experiment: Who's on?
events.abstract: A performance that is bigger on the inside.

events.title: My Container Ship Holiday Slideshow
events.abstract: This summer I went on holiday on a container ship, so this talk will be a slideshow of my holiday photos. I'll also go on tangents about supply chains, Shenzhen, shipping containers, rare earth metal mines, GPS, and that kind of thing.

events.title: Not Safe For Work: Industrial Control System Security
events.abstract: Infrastructure supports people, and it needs maintained and secured. Come learn about the challenges of securing control systems, and how you can help no matter what your background. You will laugh and you will cry, and we'll give you the whole seat, but all you'll need is THE EDGE.

events.title: Nuclear Poker Bunker
events.abstract: A half-size Hexayurt Quad Dome, within which people play Nuclear Poker, a card game designed to teach Generals too young to remember the Cold War about Mutually Assured Destruction.

events.title: Off-grid solar photovoltaics hands-on workshop
events.abstract: A hands-on workshop covering the basics of solar photovoltaic power. It will include solar PV ratings, load calculation, system design and battery bank sizing.

events.title: Open Space Projects
events.abstract: Inclusive and collaborative space projects for the techy, creative and curious and where to get started.

events.title: Origami for Geeks
events.abstract: A discipline that spans art and mathematics must surely appeal to geeks. This is a demonstration of a few simple to intermediate origami models, hopefully subjects geeks will like, with pointers to further resources to explore this absorbing hobby. I will also be conspicuously folding paper throughout the weekend in an attempt to engage anyone who shows a moment's weakness.

events.title: Our Data, Ourselves
events.abstract: I'll be talking about the "Our Data, Ourselves" project at King's College London, which been done in conjunction with some teenage coders via Young Rewired State. They are already contributing to the app, and have started to examine the data they have generated. We will report on their attitudes to privacy, how the app works, and some preliminary results.

events.title: Outdoor, Retro-pixel, art gallery! Create your own artworks and animations on a 30 x 30 outdoor pixel screen.
Perfect session management in privacy-sensitive web applications
events.subtitle: Pitfalls and testing
events.abstract: Web applications that provide sensitive data must have perfect session management. This talk will show what problems and solutions there are using web standards that work anywhere. Did you know that many frameworks are doing it wrong?

events.title: Point Of Sale Device tricks: You could…live for free!
events.abstract: Nowadays, very few people carry cash for their everyday transactions. Most of the daily transactions are performed by a debit or a credit card using a Point of Sale (POS) device. The device’s temporary storage, the card data, the overall transaction information and the established communication channel to the authorization server are protected by strong encryption and a number of security features. However, these devices have a number of “features” which can be used to allow someone to deviate from payment process in a number of different ways. More specifically, it is possible to complete a transaction without actually being charged, pay with someone else’s card without knowing the PIN or even get paid instead of paying. The presentation will give you a good understanding on how these devices work and it will basically demonstrate a number of “magic tricks” on how you could actually live for free!

events.title: Privacy Policy Receipt
events.subtitle: Get a paper receipt when you trade personal data for web services

events.title: Programming for impostors and scientists
events.abstract: A defence of shitty scientific programming. I'd like to outline some of the issues that scientists learning to code on the job might face, and also acknowledge how learning some software engineering skills will help your science progress faster and more reproducibly, with a few (not original) ideas about what those helpful things might be.

events.title: Q&A on Physical Security with the worlds greatest lock hackers
events.abstract: Join Jos Weyers, Warren Rockley, Nigel Tolley and John Naughton as they answer your questions on anything lock and physical security related.

events.title: Reading Hitler's Mind: Bletchley Park and The First Computer
events.abstract: The world's first computer, Colossus, was commissioned in 1943 just a few minutes away from the EMF camp. It gave Bletchley Park unprecedented access to the Hitler's most private communications. How did it work? Why was it built? Who designed it? All this and several shameless plugs for The National Museum of Computing.

events.title: Recreational Maths in a Field
events.subtitle: Flexagons, Folding Tube Maps & Braiding
events.abstract: I'll be presenting some interesting/unusual mathematical things I've encountered over the last few years, such as flexagons, modular origami, braiding, and perfect sine curves.

events.title: Robotics and Computer Vision with MATLAB and Simulink
events.subtitle: Connected to Arduino, Raspberry Pi and LEGO Mindstorms!
events.abstract:
In this talk I will discuss how to dramatically improve the speed and quality of your robotics and computer vision projects using MATLAB and Simulink to program your Arduino, Raspberry Pi and LEGO Mindstorms. 
Firstly, I will introduce MATLAB and Simulink, the industry standard tools used by engineers worldwide to program everything from cars engines to smartphone cameras to spacecraft navigation systems. 
Next I will give some examples of how these tools can greatly speed up the development of software for a wide range of low-cost hardware devices. Examples include, getting started with Computer Vision on a Raspberry Pi in only 3 lines of code; Programming an Arduino without learning C++ and modifying your code at runtime; Graphically designing a complex control system for a LEGO Mindstorms robot.

events.title: Rocket Mice
events.abstract: Rocket Mice! Make a little rocket, decorate it and then get to launch it off the top of a milk bottle! All ages, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. You don't need to bring anything! More info on the wiki.

events.title: Rubik's Cube speedsolving
events.abstract:
A gathering for people who like to (speed)solve Rubik's Cubes and
similar puzzles, or are just curious.

events.title: Ruby Programming for Kids
events.abstract: Basic Ruby programming for kids. Using the Codacademy labs online environment, we'll look at the fundamentals of Ruby programming and work in groups to build a small, custom program. This will likely be a small, simple game (like FizzBuzz) but I'll prepare a range of different activities to suit the actual skill level and interests of participants. Ages 10+. Bring a laptop. More info on the wiki.

events.title: Run your own infrastructure II
events.abstract: A followup talk to one given at OHM in 2013 about how to run your own infrastructure rather than relying on Google or other large companies.

events.title: Security Quiz!
events.abstract: A quiz about security!

events.title: Security Quiz!
events.abstract: A quiz about security!

events.title: Security Zone: Hands on lab
events.subtitle: Bring your own laptops!
events.abstract: For those of you who attended the introduction to basic theory to privacy and encryption or those who simply want to tool up, come and learn what software you should use and how to use it. Please bring a laptop you can install software on.

events.title: Showing keys in public
events.subtitle: What could possibly go wrong?
events.abstract: If a reporter wants to get the point across that certain people shouldn’t have access to a particular key, would it be wise for said reporter to then show that key to the world? Like the New York City subway key? The key to the subway? On the Internet?! This and other media fails will be shown. And maybe even one or two non-fail examples…. Several cases of key-copying-by-sight will be discussed with lots of pictures and videos. How this can happen will be explained, as well as what to do to prevent it.

events.title: SimPrints
events.subtitle: Low-cost fingerprint scanners for the developing world
events.abstract: We have developed a rugged, low-cost, portable fingerprint scanner and software that integrates with almost any existing mHealth application, allowing for real-time identification and access to patient records. We’re going to present our story, beginning as clueless students who managed to build a prototype from scratch in less than one year. With almost no money we tested it in the remote corners of Bangladesh, working with the largest development NGO in the world.

events.title: Singer-Songwriter Hannah Howe
events.subtitle: Original tunes and a mix of acoustic covers - something for everyone!
events.abstract: Original tunes and a mix of acoustic guitar covers - something for everyone!

events.title: Solder a Flashing LED Badge
events.abstract: Learn to solder - make a simple flashing LED badge. This workshop is also an activity in the Nottingham Hackspace Village, but this workshop will be a chance for under 18s to try out soldering in their own workshop. Ages 5+, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. £2 for the soldering kit. More info on the wiki.

events.title: Solder a 'I Can Solder Badge and Torch'
events.abstract: Basic Introduction to Soldering, using the I Can Solder Badge and I Can Solder Torch kits. The kits provides a very simple platform for people of all ages and abilities to learn how to solder. Ages 5+, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. £4 for the pair of kits. More info on the wiki.

events.title: Solder a 'I Can Solder Badge and Torch'
events.abstract: Basic Introduction to Soldering, using the I Can Solder Badge and I Can Solder Torch kits. The kits provides a very simple platform for people of all ages and abilities to learn how to solder. Ages 5+, but under 8s will need to be accompanied by a parent or carer. £4 for the pair of kits. More info on the wiki.

events.title: Stop-motion challenge
events.subtitle: Make a fantastical film at the festival
events.abstract: Film-making workshop, challenging people to use stop-motion techniques, any camera available and the EMFcamp environment to create short stop-motion movies.

events.title: Surface Mount Soldering
events.subtitle: SMD by hand isn't hard, build your own Persistence of Vision kit to prove it!
events.abstract: Surface Mount Soldering - Dispelling the often held myth that Surface Mount soldering by hand is hard. Build a Persistence of Vision kit to wave messages to fellow campers! Cost to cover kit £8.

events.title: Surreal Numbers And Mathematical Games
events.subtitle: Uppitiness, Atomic Weight and Chilling
events.abstract: John Conway created/discovered the Surreal Numbers (along with the game of life cellular automaton) while pondering the game of Go. They include all the reals and rationals you probably know but also infinite and infinitesimal values, lots of them.  Combinatorial Game Theory is an additive theory of games with perfect information and no chance element. Fortunately, though it touches on things at the core of Mathematics, it requires almost no other concepts to understand it It turns out some Games are Numbers, however any Game that is interesting enough to be worth playing is not a Number. We need a new language to describe them (whence Uppitiness, Atomic Weight and Chilling). We will find out how to play the Nim perfectly, realise Dots and Boxes has more to it than you thought, play Col, Snort and Cutcake, understand the Tweedledee and Tweedledum argument, learn Hackenbush and maybe begin to analyse Go and chess end games.

events.title: Tastes Great, Less Wordy: Document Natural Language Processing (for Beer)
events.abstract: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is among the oldest of Computer Science fields, dating back at least to the 1950s. In this talk I'll present a crash course in basic NLP, focusing on tools to perform document-level summarization and understanding. We'll use these techniques to make sense of the language people use on the web when describing beer.

events.title: Telling stories about tech
events.abstract: My job this summer is to find, tell and find new ways to tell stories about people and tech. So here are a few of my favourite stories, and some thoughts on the ideas about tech we embed when we try to tell stories about it.

events.title: The 55th Flotilla (Live)
events.subtitle: With custom-built MIDI controllers & circuit bent lovelyness
events.abstract: I write electronic music & build controllers with a nautical theme! Between playing tracks I'll answer questions about how our kit is set up and how it works.

events.title: The Archers Avoider
events.subtitle: How I learned to make my ideal radio, and you can too.
events.abstract: At BBC Research and Development, part of our job is to think about and demonstrate what radio might be like in the future. To do this effectively, we need to be able to quickly and cheaply show how our ideas would work on physical radio sets, because this is still how the majority of people listen. This talk is about techniques we've developed to do this, from helping people to describe what they want from a radio, to filtering out bad ideas ("cat wigs"), to prototyping experiences on physical devices using a Raspberry Pi and web technologies.

events.title: The digital democracy dream
events.subtitle: Could technology really improve politics, and if so, how?
events.abstract: A talk about the ways in which the internet is being used all over the world by activists and others to try and win freedoms, and improve democracy.

events.title: The Dilemmas of Sci-Fi
events.subtitle: (And How They're Dealt With)
events.abstract: Featuring some of the more well-known science-fiction shows such as Firefly, Stargate and Star Wars, I will explore some of the dilemmas featured, such as whether it is right to kill a man to secure a nation's peace, is it right to let many die to save the life of one and what ethical theories are used in these pieces, such as Utilitarianism or Kantian ethics.

events.title: The Grid
events.subtitle: An immersive art/engineering installation featuring a virtual maze -- a spectacle of interactive light and sound.

events.title: The Kinematocinegraph: Silent movies in the woods.
events.abstract: A projector, a bedsheet, and a silent movie evening in the woods.  It's a chance to see silent movies with no sound, a chance to sit out in the night air and enjoy flickering images, a chance to relax.

events.title: The Making Of The·Grid
events.abstract: We'll talk about the planning, design and construction of The·Grid, a large light and sound installation at EMF. We'll share a few stories from its development and talk about how you can write your own code to run on it, with examples.

events.title: The One Ring, make your own silver ring
events.abstract: We (you!) will be making a silver or gold forged ring, facettes of hammering will be visible and give a nice shine (or darkened if you like). This workshop will be charged for.

events.title: The Science of Hedonism and the Hedonism of Science
events.abstract: Sex, drugs and rock and roll are ancient indulgences: we are hooked, and have been since the very beginning. Modern science has revealed why these "base" pursuits define our species. But moreover, scientific innovations have been used to revolutionise how we get laid, get high and rock out. Our highest intellectual achievements combined with our primal pursuits has led to countless spectacular outcomes that continue to change the experience of being human.

events.title: The Security of the Internet of Things
events.subtitle: Curtains and Power Plants
events.abstract: A talk about the current state of security in internet-enabled embedded devices with a variety of sensors and actuators, from curtains through home automation systems to full-scale power plants. With plenty of actual examples.

events.title: The softprinter
events.subtitle: A 3D printer that makes clothes
events.abstract: A talk about the OpenKnit project, and a demonstration of a working prototype.

events.title: The three main parties railroaded the Data Retention Act through in a week. Where does the fightback begin?
events.abstract: The three party leaders made a secret deal to pass the Data Retention and Investigatory Powers Act in less than a week. Using the overbearing power of the executive, a legislature agreed legislation that allows the security services access to your entire data footprint for a year. Faced with such a blatant display of political muscle how does a concerned citizen fight back? I don't have all the answers but I have a few ideas.

events.title: The ZX Spectrum - a secret history
events.abstract: Matt Westcott has followed the Spectrum's journey first-hand into obscurity and back again as an object of nostalgia - this is its story, told through personal experiences and a backdrop of world history. Learn how the ZX Spectrum served as a beacon of hope during the Sarajevo war, slipped under the Iron Curtain to find a new set of devotees, and sent its first tweet from an Oxford pub...

events.title: Trials and tribulations of a badge project
events.abstract: How TiLDA MKe went from a list of Ideas the week before EMW, to epaper and finally the to the badge around your neck. With all the bumps along the way.

events.title: UCL Family Geek Showoff
events.abstract: A series of short, funny, geeky talks by people who know their stuff, hosted by Steve Cross. Family friendly and fun for everyone.

events.title: UCL Geek Showoff
events.abstract: A series of short, funny, geeky talks by people who know their stuff, hosted by Steve Cross. This show will not be suitable for children!

events.title: USB tinkering for hackers and makers
events.abstract: We have written USBProxy, an open source software tool targeted at cheap hardware, such as the BeagleBone Black, which allows us to build, explore and break USB devices with simple software. I will show how we can use USBProxy to monitor and debug USB connections and how we can build a USB device in software using £35 of hardware.

events.title: Vandalising your Github commit history for fun and profit
events.abstract: Why would anybody feel the need to create a webservice for writing graffiti on a Github commit history graph, when there are real problems that need solving? Come and find out in this talk, which also features the Sinclair Spectrum font and a brief exploration of the Github API.

events.title: Walt Disney World: This was supposed to be the future
events.abstract: A short talk on the legislative history of Disney World. It's not *quite* as boring as it sounds.

events.title: We don't need no stinkin' tension wrenches
events.abstract: You thought two hackers, one keyboard was bad? Just wait until you see what hollywood does to lockpickers. From no-contact lockpicking to real rocks in a fake keys, and from reasonably realistic heists to 'fuck it, we'll do it live', we'll overview the diverse manner in which lockpickers and lockpicking are portrayed in the media.

events.title: What do we have in Computers?
events.abstract: At the moment there is a priestly cult around people who know the secrets of computers, we are treated well because we are scarce - like scribes in ancient Egypt, and we are similarly instruments of power, can we afford to ignore it? But what happens when *everyone* can do it?

events.title: Where Games Break
events.abstract: A gently performative, slightly poetic talk on the ways games break; in personal and political, difficult and perfect ways.

events.title: Why are computers so @#!*, and what can we do about it?
events.abstract: Computers have become ubiquitous and essential, but they remain massively error-prone and insecure - as if we were back in the early days of the industrial revolution, with steam engines exploding left, right, and centre. Why is this, and can we do better?

events.title: Wood turning
events.abstract: We'll be turning up with a lathe, some wood and pointy sharp things.  We have a stack of bowl blanks and some spindle blanks and will be doing some turning ourselves.  We're also happy to show people how to do some turning at their own risk.

events.title: Zoë Star; Neurotic IoT Machines from an Alternate Reality
events.abstract: Raspberry Pis creative producer talks about a personal R&D project - Interactive satirical art works poking fun at Internet of Things, Quantified Self and Digital Natives.
